case_name: Government of Madras v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1468-69 of 1967 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1468-69 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeals directed against judgment and decree dated April 10, 1962 of High Court of Madras in A.S. Nos. 63 and 78 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th April, 1962 of the High Court of Madras in Appeal Suit Nos. 63 and 78 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals, by certificate, are directed against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madras

facts.text: Appellant is the Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Government of Madras, acquired 9 acres and 86 cents of land

facts.text: Government of Madras acquired 9 acres and 86 cents of land in Tirunelveli District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Government of Madras, acquired 9 acres and 86 cents of land in Tirunelveli District as it was needed

facts.text: Land acquired for reserve area in Block III of Manimuthar Project.

anchor.surface_text: in Tirunelveli District as it was needed for reserve area in Block III of Manimuthar Project.

facts.text: Notification under section 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act published on March 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification under s. 4 1  of the Land Acquisition Act was published on March 7, 1956.

facts.text: Area concerned is one acre and 59 cents comprised of 3 topes of coconuts and oranges.

anchor.surface_text: The area of the land with which we are companycerned in this appeal is one acre and 59 cents companyprised of 3 topes, of companyonuts and oranges,

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer gave total compensation of Rs. 28,572-15-6 inclusive of solarium.

anchor.surface_text: The Land Acquisition Officer, by his award, gave a total companypensation of Rs. 28,572-15-6 inclusive of solarium.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer valued coconut and orange topes by capitalizing net income at 20 years purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The method adopted by him for valuing companyonut and orange lopes was to capitalize the net income from these lopes at 20 years purchase.

facts.text: Respondent dissatisfied with award and moved for reference under section 18 of Land Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: Dissatisfied with the award he respondent moved for reference under s. 18 of the Land Acquisition Act and the case was referred

facts.text: Case referred to Subordinate Judge, Tirunelveli.

anchor.surface_text: to the Subordinate Judge, Tirunelveli. The learned Subordinate Judge increased the estimated yield

facts.text: Subordinate Judge increased estimated yield from coconut and orange trees and price of yield, capitalized net income at 20 years purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge increased the estimated yield from the companyonut and orange trees as well as the price of the yield but capitalized the net income at 20 years purchase.

facts.text: State of Madras filed A.S. No. 63 of 1959 against Subordinate Judge decision.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, the State of Madras filed S. No. 63 of 1959, while the respondent filed A.S. No. 78 of 1959

facts.text: Respondent filed A.S. No. 78 of 1959 claiming further enhancement.

anchor.surface_text: , while the respondent filed A.S. No. 78 of 1959 claiming a further enhancement.

facts.text: High Court by common judgment allowed the appeals in part and dismissed in other respects.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by the companymon judgment under appeal, allowed the appeals in part and dismissed them in other respects.

facts.text: High Court held capitalization of net income at 20 years purchase fair method for market value of coconut and orange topes.

anchor.surface_text: As regardrs the companyonut and orange topes, the High Court held that capitalization of the net income at 20 years purchase was a fair method for arriving at their market value.

facts.text: In Supreme Court appeal, only point argued was High Court wrong in capitalizing net income of topes at 20 years purchase.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, the only point argued by companynsel was the High Court went wrong in capitalizing the net income of the topes at 20 years purchase.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant relied on Madras High Court decision in Shunmuga Velavuda Mudaliar v. Collector of Tanjore holding capitalize coconut garden net income at 10 years purchase.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel relied on the. decision of the Madras High Court in Shunmuga Velavuda Mudaliar and others V. Collector of Tanjore 1  where it was held that the proper method to find out the market value of companyonut garden would be to capitalize the net income from the garden at 10 years purchase

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer found in award that all fruit bearing trees will yield for more than 20 years.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the Land Acquisition Officer found in his award that all the fruit bearing trees will yield for more than 20 years.

facts.text: That was the reason which weighed with Land Acquisition Officer to capitalize net income at 20 years purchase.

anchor.surface_text: That was A.I.R. 1926 Mad. 945  2 . A.I.R. 1959 A.P. 52 at 62.  3  43 Ind. Cas 17 2  A.I.R. 1918 Pat. 625 2   Q . the reason which weighed with him to capitalize the net income of these topes at 20 years purchase

facts.text: Supreme Court holds learned Subordinate Judge and High Court did not go wrong in accepting estimate of average yielding life of coconut and orange trees.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the learned Subordinate Judge and the High Court went wrong in accepting this estimate of, the average yielding life of companyonut and orange trees.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds capitalization of net yield from topes at 20 years purchase was a fair method to arrive at market value.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think that the capi- talization of the number yield from these topes at 20 years, purchase was number a fair, method to arrive at the market value of these topes.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds method of valuation adopted for market value of topes was not unreasonable in the circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We are number satisfied that the method of valuation adopted for finding out the market value of the topes was. in the circumstances, in any way unreasonable.

facts.text: Appeals fail and dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts.
The numberification under s. 4 1  of the Land Acquisition Act was published on March 7, 1956.

issues.text: Whether the High Court went wrong in capitalizing the net income of the coconut and orange topes at 20 years purchase to arrive at their market value

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, the only point argued by companynsel was the High Court went wrong in capitalizing the net income of the topes at 20 years purchase. Counsel relied on the. decision

arguments.claim: High Court went wrong in capitalizing net income of coconut and orange topes at 20 years purchase; proper method is to capitalize at 10 years purchase as held in Shunmuga Velavuda Mudaliar v. Collector of Tanjore

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, the only point argued by companynsel was the High Court went wrong in capitalizing the net income of the topes at 20 years purchase. Counsel relied on the. decision of the Madras High Court in Shunmuga Velavuda Mudaliar and others V. Collector of Tanjore 1  where it was held that the proper method to find out the market value of coconut garden would be to capitalize the net income from the garden at 10 years purchase

court_response_anchor.surface_text: their market value. In this appeal, the only point argued by companynsel was the High Court went wrong in capitalizing the net income of the topes at

arguments.court_reasoning: No reason given in Shunmuga for 10 years; other precedents used 15-20 years based on tree nature; LAO evidence shows trees yield over 20 years; lower courts' acceptance not wrong

arguments.claim: No reason given in Shunmuga Velavuda Mudaliar for capitalizing coconut garden net income at 10 years purchase; referenced Rajammal where mango topes valued at 20 years as long-lived trees

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbered that numberreason was given in that ruling why capitalization of the net income should be at 10 years purchase. All that the Court said was In Rajammal, v. Head Quarters Deputy Collector, Vellore  1914  25 I.C. 393, a Bench of this Court estimated the value of a tope of trees at 20 years annual rental but those were mango trees which as stated by the learned Judges, are long lived and yield produce for a number of years.

arguments.claim: Approved method for valuing orchards is to capitalize net income at number of years purchase fixed with reference to nature of trees and other circumstances, as in Kompalli Nageshwara Rao v. Special Deputy Collector where 15 years used for coconut and orange

anchor.surface_text: In Kompalli Nageshwara Rao Others v. Special Deputy Collector, Land Acquisition  2   the Court said that the approved method for valuing orchards is to capitalize their net income at a number of years purchase which has to be fixed with reference to the nature of the trees and other circumstances and capitalized the net income at 15 years purchase for finding out the market value of the coconut garden and the orange orchard in question-in that case.

arguments.claim: Net income from orchard capitalized at 15 years purchase to find market value, as in Elias M. Cohen v. Secy. of State

anchor.surface_text: In Elias M. Cohen v. Secy. of State 3 , the net income from an orchard was capitalized at 15 years purchase to find out its market value.

arguments.claim: All fruit bearing trees will yield for more than 20 years, which is reason to capitalize net income of topes at 20 years purchase

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the Land Acquisition Officer found in his award that all the fruit bearing trees will yield for more than 20 years. That was A.I.R. 1926 Mad. 945  2 . A.I.R. 1959 A.P. 52 at 62.  3  43 Ind. Cas 17 2  A.I.R. 1918 Pat. 625 2   Q . the reason which weighed with him to capitalize the net income of these topes at 20 years purchase to find out their market value.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion in the judgment of the principle on the basis of which such a mode of calculation was adopted. In Kompalli Nageshwa

arguments.court_reasoning: Learned Subordinate Judge and High Court did not go wrong in accepting this estimate of average yielding life of coconut and orange trees

arguments.claim: Learned Subordinate Judge and High Court did not go wrong in accepting estimate of average yielding life of coconut and orange trees as more than 20 years

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the learned Subordinate Judge and the High Court went wrong in accepting this estimate of, the average yielding life of companyonut and orange trees.

arguments.claim: Capitalization of net yield from topes at 20 years purchase was a fair method to arrive at market value

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think that the capi- talization of the number yield from these topes at 20 years, purchase was number a fair, method to arrive at the market value of these topes.

arguments.claim: Method of valuation adopted for market value of topes was not unreasonable in the circumstances

anchor.surface_text: We are number satisfied that the method of valuation adopted for finding out the market value of the topes was. in the circumstances, in any way unreasonable.

arguments.claim: Capitalization of net income at 20 years purchase was a fair method for arriving at market value of coconut and orange topes

anchor.surface_text: As regardrs the companyonut and orange topes, the High Court held that capitalization of the net income at 20 years purchase was a fair method for arriving at their market value.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a Rao Others v. Special Deputy Collector, Land Acquisition  2   the Court said that the approved method for valuing orchards is to capitalize their ne

arguments.court_reasoning: Fair given tree yielding life over 20 years and circumstances

holdings.text: The learned Subordinate Judge and the High Court did not go wrong in accepting the estimate of the average yielding life of coconut and orange trees as more than 20 years

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the learned Subordinate Judge and the High Court went wrong in accepting this estimate of, the average yielding life of companyonut and orange trees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Land Acquisition Officer found all fruit bearing trees will yield for more than 20 years; lower courts accepted this estimate

holdings.text: Capitalization of the net yield from the coconut and orange topes at 20 years purchase was a fair method to arrive at their market value

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do number think that the capi- talization of the number yield from these topes at 20 years, purchase was number a fair, method to arrive at the market value of these topes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trees yield more than 20 years; approved orchard valuation method capitalizes net income at years purchase based on tree nature and circumstances; precedents use 15-20 years

holdings.text: The method of valuation adopted for finding out the market value of the topes was not unreasonable in the circumstances

anchor.surface_text: We are number satisfied that the method of valuation adopted for finding out the market value of the topes was. in the circumstances, in any way unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Capitalization at 20 years purchase fair given yielding life over 20 years, precedents distinguished and followed

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court did not err in upholding capitalization method for market value
